posts.content:
Student: John Smith
March 15, 2025

            I found the reading on artificial intelligence really fascinating, especially the part about machine learning algorithms. However, I'm struggling to understand how neural networks actually work in practice. 
            
            The textbook explanation is quite theoretical, and I'm wondering if anyone can provide a more practical example? Also, what are the main differences between supervised and unsupervised learning? I think I get the basic concept, but I'm not sure about the applications.
            
            Looking forward to the discussion!
posts.author: Student: John Smith

posts.content:
I found the reading on artificial intelligence really fascinating, especially the part about machine learning algorithms. However, I'm struggling to understand how neural networks actually work in practice. 
            
            The textbook explanation is quite theoretical, and I'm wondering if anyone can provide a more practical example? Also, what are the main differences between supervised and unsupervised learning? I think I get the basic concept, but I'm not sure about the applications.
            
            Looking forward to the discussion!
posts.author: Unknown

posts.content:
Student: Emily Chen
March 15, 2025

            @John I had similar questions! From what I understood, supervised learning is like having a teacher - you give the algorithm examples with the "right answers" so it can learn patterns. Like showing it thousands of photos labeled "cat" or "dog" so it learns to recognize them.
            
            Unsupervised learning is more like letting the algorithm find patterns on its own without giving it the answers first. It might group similar things together without being told what to look for.
            
            As for neural networks, I think of them like a simplified brain - layers of connected "neurons" that process information and pass it along. But I'm still fuzzy on the technical details too.
posts.author: Student: Emily Chen
Unknown

posts.content:
Student: Mike Rodriguez
March 16, 2025

            Great discussion so far! I found this helpful analogy for neural networks: imagine you're trying to recognize handwritten numbers. The first layer of neurons might detect simple lines and curves, the second layer combines these into shapes, and the final layer puts it all together to recognize the complete number.
            
            Each "neuron" looks at the input, applies some math, and decides how strongly to activate. The connections between neurons have different weights that get adjusted during training.
            
            For practical applications, I've been experimenting with some online tutorials. TensorFlow has some good beginner examples if anyone wants to try coding some basic models.
posts.author: Student: Mike Rodriguez

posts.subject: 📚1.1 Accessing Article A: Your First Academic Reading Adventure
posts.message:
🕵️‍♀️ Academic Detective Challenge!

Hello everyone! 👋

Welcome to your first academic research task! Instead of giving you the direct link, let's practice the essential skill of finding academic articles - something you'll do constantly in university.

📖 Article A - Basic Information:

Title: Supporting schools to use face recognition systems: a continuance intention perspective of elementary school parents in China
Authors: Hong, J. C., Li, Y., & Kuo, S. Y.
Year: 2022
Journal: Education and Information Technologies
DOI: 10.1007/s10639-022-11084-7

🎯 Your Mission:

  1. Find the article online using the information above
  2. Access the full article (try multiple approaches if needed)
  3. Reply to this post with:
    • The direct link you found
    • What search strategy worked for you
    • What format options are available (PDF, HTML, etc.)
    • Any access challenges you encountered

💡 Search Strategies to Try:

  • 🔍 Google Scholar search with title/authors
  • 🏫 HKBU Library database
  • 🌐 DOI resolver (hint: try doi.org)
  • 📚 Direct publisher website search

📚 Why Locating and Managing Information Matters:

  • Builds Research Skills: Locating academic articles hones your ability to navigate scholarly resources, a critical skill for university success.
  • Supports Academic Success: Efficiently finding and organizing information ensures you can access key materials for assignments and exams.
  • Enhances Time Management: Using systems like Getting Things Done (GTD) helps you organize documents in a structured way, reducing stress and improving productivity.
  • Familiarizes with Library Systems: Mastering the HKBU Library database and other academic tools prepares you for independent research and lifelong learning.
  • Centralized Document Storage: Keep all your academic documents (e.g., PDFs, notes) in a dedicated folder or cloud system like Google Drive or OneDrive, as part of your GTD workflow, for easy access and reference.

🤝 Collaboration Encouraged!

If someone finds the link, others can still practice different search methods and share their experiences!
